definitions.definition: a long narrow piece of leather, cloth, etc. that you wear around the middle part of your body

examples.text: Around his waist he wore a belt.

definitions.definition: a continuous band of material that moves round and is used to carry things along or to drive a machine
a narrow area or an area around the edge of something that has particular characteristics

examples.text: a belt of rain moving across the country
Towns in the country's industrial belt were particularly affected by the recession.

definitions.definition: an act of hitting something/somebody hard

examples.text: She gave the ball a terrific belt.
That was distinctly below the belt!

definitions.definition: taking more actions than are really necessary to make sure that something succeeds or works as it should
to have already achieved or obtained something

examples.text: She already has a couple of good wins under her belt.

definitions.definition: to spend less money because there is less available

examples.text: With price increases on most goods, everyone is having to tighten their belt.
There is a need for further belt-tightening.

wordOrigin: Old English, of Germanic origin, from Latin balteus ‘girdle’.
